title: Murder on the Orient Express
summary:
A snowbound luxury train hides a brutal stabbing.
Detective Hercule Poirot interviews suspects one by one amid isolation.
Themes of deception, justice versus legality, and collective guilt drive the mystery.

title: The Catcher in the Rye
summary:
Holden Caulfield roams wintery New York after expulsion.
He rails against phoniness while craving authenticity and childhood innocence.
Alienation, identity crisis, rebellion and coming‑of‑age shape his cynical voice.

title: Milk and Honey
summary:
Four poetic sections—hurting, loving, breaking, healing—trace a woman's journey.
Minimalist verse confronts trauma, abuse and patriarchy with raw honesty.
Themes of love, feminism, empowerment and personal healing invite reflection.

Winston Smith secretly rebels against Big Brother’s all‑seeing Party.
He clings to truth and love under relentless surveillance and propaganda.
Totalitarianism, language control, fear and the fight for freedom dominate the dystopia.

title: Brave New World
summary:
In a test‑tube society kept docile by pleasure and the drug soma.
Outsiders question whether engineered happiness is worth individuality and art.
Technology, social control, consumerism and the cost of freedom anchor the satire.

title: Fahrenheit 451
summary:
Fireman Guy Montag burns books until curiosity sparks a hidden hunger for ideas.
Encounters with a free spirit and secret readers shatter his conformity.
Censorship, intellectual freedom and media-driven apathy blaze through the narrative.

title: The Hobbit
summary:
Home‑loving Bilbo Baggins joins dwarves on a perilous quest to the Lonely Mountain.
Trolls, elves, and a dragon test his courage as friendship deepens.
Adventure, greed, loyalty and the hero’s journey illuminate this fantasy.

title: To Kill a Mockingbird
summary:
Scout Finch observes her father defend a Black man in 1930s Alabama.
The trial exposes racial injustice while childhood games teach empathy.
Themes of moral growth, prejudice, compassion and innocence converge.

title: Educated
summary:
Tara Westover grows up off‑grid with survivalist parents who distrust schools.
Self‑study propels her from junkyard to Cambridge, straining family bonds.
Education, self‑discovery, loyalty and coming‑of‑age frame this memoir.

title: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind
summary:
Harari condenses 300,000 years of Homo sapiens into a sweeping narrative.
He argues shared myths like money and religion enable massive cooperation.
Human evolution, culture and cognition challenge readers to reconsider progress.

title: Pride and Prejudice
summary:
Quick‑witted Elizabeth Bennet spars with the aloof Mr. Darcy.
Misjudgments unravel amid balls, gossip and family pressures in Regency England.
Social class, marriage, coming‑of‑age and self‑knowledge steer their romance.

title: The Alchemist
summary:
Shepherd Santiago dreams of treasure and crosses deserts seeking destiny.
Guided by omens, he meets kings, alchemists and learns the soul of the world.
Personal legend, faith, perseverance and following one’s heart form the fable.

title: The Fault in Our Stars
summary:
Cancer patient Hazel meets survivor Augustus at a support group.
Their whirlwind romance confronts pain, joy, and the search for meaning.
Love, mortality, illness and coming-of-age intertwine in this poignant young-adult tale.
